child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1977. A Handbook of Comparative Tai, Oceanic Linguistics Special Publications, Oceanic Linguistics, vol. 15. , Li, Fang-Kuei. 1960. A Tentative Classification of Tai Dialects. In Stanley Diamond (ed.), Culture in History: Essays in Honor of Paul Radin, 951–959. New York: Columbia University Press.
child.pub-comments: The dialect names T'ien-pao, Yung-ch'un, Ch'ien-chiang, Ling-yun, Hsi-lin, T'ien-chow, and Po-ai represent the district names in China where the author gathered data on these dialects. He indicates that other names have been used for these dialects, such as Chung-chia, Chuang-chia, Thu (Tho), etc., but that he avoids them "because they have been used too vaguely to be of scientific significance" (Li 1960:958).
child.geography: In the western part of Kwangsi

child.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1977. A Handbook of Comparative Tai, Oceanic Linguistics Special Publications, Oceanic Linguistics, vol. 15. , Li, Fang-Kuei. 1960. A Tentative Classification of Tai Dialects. In Stanley Diamond (ed.), Culture in History: Essays in Honor of Paul Radin, 951–959. New York: Columbia University Press.
child.geography: Around the district of Ts'e-heng in the southwestern part of Kweichow

He indicates that other names have been used for these dialects, such as Chung-chia, Chuang-chia, Thu (Tho), etc., but that he avoids them "because they have been used too vaguely to be of scientific significance" (Li 1960:958).

child.geography: Spoken in the town of Po-ai, formerly belonging to the district of Fu-ning in Yunnan province; the district is in the south-eastern corner of Yunnan near the border of Kwangsi

root.publications: Li, Fang-Kuei. 1977. A Handbook of Comparative Tai, Oceanic Linguistics Special Publications, Oceanic Linguistics, vol. 15. , Li, Fang-Kuei. 1960. A Tentative Classification of Tai Dialects. In Stanley Diamond (ed.), Culture in History: Essays in Honor of Paul Radin, 951–959. New York: Columbia University Press.
root.pub-comments: Li mostly calls the lects in this tree "dialects" but also occasionally refers to some/all of them as "languages," somewhat interchangeably; he doesn't specify a distinction between the two terms. For the purposes of this representation, all lects are categorized as dialects.
root.geography: Spoken in a fairly large area in Southeast Asia and in China, consisting of Thailand, Laos, the northern part of Vietnam, West Burman (Shan states), and Southwest China
